s1: Cyber Security Foundations introduces all essential cyber security principles.
s2: Prove simple programs correct using Hoare Logic.

s1: This includes principles of secure design, secrets minimization, least privilege, isolation, separation and encapsulation.
s2: The following areas of study constitute the backbone of the course. Predicate calculus and natural deduction, inductive definitions of data types as a basis for recursive functions and structural induction, formal language theory (particularly regular expressions, finite state machines and context free grammars), and specification languages.

s1: The interplay between failed security principles and vulnerabilities is investigated in detail.
s2: Prove simple programs correct using Hoare Logic.

s1: The course provides the essential foundations which allow students to continue in a more in-depth cyber security career, yet can also be used a standalone unit to provide a self-contained set of knowledge.
s2: Apply the concepts of standard mathematical logic to produce proofs or refutations of well-formed propositions or arguments phrased in English or in a variety of formal notations (first order logic, discrete mathematics or Hoare Logic).

s1: Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the fundamental principles underlying Cyber Security.
s2: Design a Turing Machine which will accomplish simple tasks.
